Award.AwardTitle: ALOHA Cabled Observatory: Operations and Maintenance
Award.AbstractNarration:
The ALOHA Cabled Observatory (ACO) was deployed in June 2011 to support innovative scientific research at Station ALOHA, 100 km north of Oahu. For the past 23 years on a monthly schedule, the Hawai'i Ocean Time-series (HOT) project has been collecting ship-based oceanographic data; for the last 7 years, the WHOTS mooring has provided comprehensive meteorological and upper ocean data. These data together with those from associated process studies form a unique, multivariate long-term data set of the ocean state centered at one location. The PI's request funding to continued ACO operations and maintenance for the scientific community.

Broader Impacts:

A successful full-ocean-depth cabled observatory available to the research community will have broad impacts on both ocean science and in communicating the importance of our work to students and the interested public. The PIs do a great job explaining how they will entrain the ocean science community, including both hosting instruments on the cabled observatory and supporting instruments that will yield data useful to the science community. Involving engineering students from UH is excellent and outreach to the local science museum will allow the many visitors to Hawaii to understand and appreciate the deep-sea beneath the blue surface. The ALOHA site also has a unique advantage being associated with the HOT time-series station. Also the proposed collaboration with the Bishop Museum seems well founded and beneficial to middle school learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ALOHA Cabled Observatory (ACO) was deployed June 2011 to support scientific research at Station ALOHA, 100 km north of Oahu. At 4728 m, it is the deepest operating plug-and-play observatory on the planet, operating now for more than 5 years. There have been two service cruises, one in November 2014 (added instruments and recovered one), and a second one in September 2015 (an additional instrument package deployed; could not recover several failed instruments), see Figure 1.

Three results highlight the need for continuous, sustained observations to detect rare episodic events:

  • During 6 weeks of video monitoring, 15 deep-sea species were observed roughly every 40 minutes. The most visually striking observation was a deep-sea lizard fish attacking an aristeid shrimp, Figure 2. This is the first observation of this behavior, allowing an evaluation of swimming kinematics.
  • Temperature data show 30 mK cold events, dynamic oscillations, and slow recovery (months to years, see Figure 3); other data indicate an associated boundary layer with a scale height of about 100 m. These events are thought to be related to episodic cold overflows from a neighboring basin. Such events are likely occurring in many other abyssal locations with strong implications for climate studies.
  • Pressure and fluorescence/turbidity were added to the core measurements in 2015. There is one event seen to date showing correlated high current speed and turbidity, indicating enough near bottom energy to stir up sediment. During this time period no fluorescence signal was detected, at odds with earlier sediment trap data of surface export events.

The ACO pressure data are being streamed now to the Pacific Tsunami Warning Center, providing direct, realtime data for tsunami warning for Hawaii; it is also being used to study the transit of Hurricane Lester overhead. Further, the acoustic hydrophone data is being analyzed to understand how water-borne earthquake signals going over the Kauai-Oahu sill make it to the ACO in the abyss.

The ACO is providing continuous bottom “essential ocean variable” data, specifically temperature, salinity, oxygen, velocity, and acoustics, complementing and extending the now-28 year, coarsely sampled Hawaii Ocean Timeseries data set.  All these data are freely and publicly available in near realtime via standard data servers (e.g., ftp and OPeNDAP).  The data services also allow collaborative programs to integrate the data.  As one example, the ACO data are presented on the Pacific Island Ocean Observing System (PacIOOS; a regional association of the Integrated Ocean Observing System) web portal and data viewer.

The ACO is a modest-scale and cost-effective cabled observatory that reuses a retired submarine telecommunication system, an outgrowth of decades of effort started by F. Duennebier, that provided the basis for all subsequent observatories. ACO is used and presented in classes on ocean acoustics and in ocean engineering laboratory classes. Undergraduate engineering majors designed and built instrument frames and ocean engineering MS students have assisted with preparing equipment. Two masters students have complete projects related to the ACO on the detection of fin and sei whales and real time engineering diagnostic software and video streaming.
